items.content_html:
Description

XSLTProcessor methods were not documented.

Motivation

openwebdocs/project#152

Additional details

I decided not to jump into a couple of rabbit holes here. There will be follow-up PRs:

  • Even if I created a missing GroupData entry, I didn't improve the guides under XSLTProcessor, as they need a significant revision, especially as they may be partial duplicates of other guides under Web/XSLT!
  • I didn't morph the Introduction guide into an overview page. This must be done to access these guides by navigating from the reference pages. (This is the duality of {{DefaultSidebarAPI}} and {{APIRef}} where we need to reach the overview page to switch from one to the other.)
  • Once these 2 follow-up PRs are done, it will be straightforward to add the missing Examples section missing here.

I wanted to avoid making this PR into a complete revamp of the area: it would have complicated the review of this PR, but I plan to do the 3 follow-up PRs mentioned above.
items.title: Document XSLTProcessor.*

items.content_html:
Description

This PR adds font-palette and font-variant-emoji to the lists of allowable properties of ::first-letter and ::first-line.

Motivation

The spec says that all font properties can be specified on these two pseudo-elements, and the current lists on the MDN pages lack these two properties.

Additional details

This PR might not be correct due to the phrasing in the spec. See w3c/csswg-drafts#8635.

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Adding font properties to allowable properties of `::first-*`

items.content_html:
Hello! I've been having 100% success with the "try it yourself" stuff in the guide (starting from 0 in HTML, thru the end of the CSS section. This is the one place I was really scratching my head... It really felt like most of the css was not applying here. While I was writing you an issue on GH, I accidentally found why it wasn't working -- my window was too narrow. All I saw was the original column of text, but a little prettier.

Might be nice to have some sort of warning about this on the page. I'm sure you all can find better words, though! :)

Btw, this guide has been THE BOMB. Thank you so much for doing what you all do! Seriously!! The embedded videos are great too!

Description

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update index.md

items.content_html:
Description

This is in scope of the PWA docs project: mdn/mdn#280

In this project, we are adding a number of new How-To pages that teach users how to implement common PWA scenarios.

This PR adds a new How-To page that demonstrates how PWAs can share data via the OS sharing dialog, as well as receive data from it.

Motivation

Sharing data, and receiving shared data, can make an app feel more naturally integrated into the OS it's installed on, and just more familiar to users. Showing that PWAs can do this just as well as native apps is something worth documenting on MDN.

This How-To relies on the Web Share API, which is already doc'd on MDN and well supported.

It also relies on the Web Share Target API, also doc'd on MDN, but only supported in Chromium.
items.title: PWA docs - New How-To page about sharing data between apps

items.content_html:
Description

  1. Opera 94+ support HEVC.
  2. Add more container that supports HEVC.
  3. Browser's HEVC support actually heavily depends on the OS and device, so update more detail.

Motivation

Since the support heavily depends on OS and hardware devices due to license reason. We better make developer clear what's the support status of this codec on each platform.

Additional details

The following is the basis for reference.

Can I Use: HEVC
Chrome Status: link
enable-chromium-hevc-hardware-decoding: link

Related issues and pull requests

Relates to #23519
items.title: Update the information about HEVC support status

items.content_html:
Description

Improves the description of the RegExp.prototype.unicode page.

Motivation

The current wording is in my opinion misleading and possibly even incorrect:

will be interpreted as such instead of as literal characters

The expressions will not be treated as literal characters, but instead \ is possibly ignored and the other characters might be interpreted as other Regex expressions. The new changes add an (potentially surprising) example for this.
items.title: Improve `RegExp.prototype.unicode` description

items.content_html:
Description

This PR rewrites the existing guide pages for the Performance API.

  • Previously, parts of the Performance API like User Timing, Resource Timing, Navigation Timing etc. were documented separately. This PR moves all guide material under Web/API/Performance_API/*.
  • The first guide is about Performance data and presents how to generally work with Performance data and what sorts of things can be measured.
  • The second guide is all about time and gives an overview how time works within the Performance API.
  • The following guides are about the individual parts of the Performance API, starting with Resource Timing, Navigation Timing and User Timing. There are more guides to be written here, but I wanted to take a break at this point.

Also, there are ideas about "How-to" and Tutorial pages, these will be written in a later PR, too.

Motivation

openwebdocs/project#62

Additional details

What sorts of review I'm looking for:

  • Is the overall structure good and should I continue to build upon it?
  • Review of the first 5 guides.

I know there are other Performance API guide pages in other trees on MDN, I would like to redirect/rework them in a follow-up PR. If you know of some pages somewhere, please send them to me.

Related issues and pull requests

None yet but I will create a PR against dom-examples to remove the entire folder of outdated example code https://github.com/mdn/dom-examples/tree/main/performance-apis
items.title: Rewrite Performance API guide pages

items.content_html:
Description

The warning on -webkit-scrollbar is currently a bit misleading - it makes it sound as if the scrollbar-color and scrollbar-width methods have more support, when in fact they have far less - only Firefox supports them. This edit attempts to make that clearer.

Motivation

I think it's important that users don't mistakenly use the scrollbar-width, scrollbar-color methods thinking they have broader support, when in fact they have far less. I think it's also important that MDN appear impartial, and not appear to favor Firefox by implying that something only Firefox supports is standard.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Updating warning around -webkit-scroll
